Firstly to Job, at the start of the book of Job there is an introduction in where the book of Job is explained. I have the "Good News Bible" version and in this introduction it says:

 So from the statement (s) above I would like you to note the words in particular "poetic". Job is written in a poetic form. Now, poetry has never been my strong suit in English, but I know enough that very few things are to be taken literally and all images have different interpretations. For instance, in this year we are studying poetry by Australian poet Peter Skrzynecki - a former immigrant who moved here after WWII. Let me tell you, I hate poetry. In one of his poems that we are studying, "Immigrants at Central Station, 1951" in which he writes:
 "Families stood with blankets and packed cases - keeping children by their sides, watching pigeons that watched them."
 I would never have thought that the pigeons are symbols of freedom, would you? Further evidence that in poetry, everything is not as it seems. 
 
 Also note the language used in Job 26:7. "He hung [or suspends] the Earth in empty space." (Good News Bible version). Notice that there is no reference to God still holding the Earth. It all depends on how you want to take or interpret it. When you suspend something what does that mean? The problem is the way that passages are worded in different versions. The Good News Bible makes it pretty clear that God hung the Earth in empty space. I would take it that all of the versions of the Bible, including the NIV, KJV and so on, should mean the same thing. So by following this logic, the NIV phrase "suspends" has the same meaning as the Good News Bible when it says "hung". 
 
 I also consulted the dictionary, not that it helped much, to find a meaning of the word "suspend". It gave many meanings, one of which was, "hang up", the other was "sustained or floating between top and bottom". So the dictionary says to suspend is to hang up. So if we apply it to Job 26:7, "He suspends the Earth in empty space" can be re-interpreted to say "He hangs the Earth in empty space".
